title: Ray Dalio keeps finding scary new ways to warn about mounting US debt
description: Bridgewater founder Ray Dalio has compared the debt threat to cancer, plaque, storms, and death spirals.
content: Ray Dalio fears America is headed for a debt crisis — and keeps finding ever-more colorful ways to warn people about it.The US debt has roughly tripled over the past 20 years to around $37 trillion, and annual interest payments now stand at around $1 trillion.On an episode of the "Modern Wisdom" podcast released this week, Dalio said that America's debt headache is "like being on a boat headed to rocks."Even though the politicians can see the danger, he said, they're "arguing about how to turn" as they're worried about angering voters by raising taxes or cutting benefits. He summed up his frustration with the status quo: "So, politics."The billionaire founder of Bridgewater Associates has been warning of the dangers of debt since at least 2018, when he published "Principles for Navigating Big Debt Crises."In the book, he argued that large amounts of borrowing inflate a bubble, which is followed by a contraction once the debts become unpayable. Pointing to the financial crisis a decade earlier and other past debacles, he argued that a debt cycle follows a predictable progression like a "disease."In late 2022, Dalio told the Greenwich Economic Forum that debt, political division, and foreign wars were a "perfect storm" facing the country. In February this year, he said that "debt accumulates like plaque" in a financial system and could result in a "heart attack" for the US economy in the form of the central government and central bank going broke.Dalio wrote in his latest book, "How Countries Go Broke," that "debt problems spread very quickly, like an aggressive cancer."He also said that the US debt is close to triggering a death spiral in which the government needs to borrow more to cover the interest on its debt, and interest rates rise as holding US dollars and Treasurys becomes riskier.Many economists have warned that the government's interest payments could grow so large that it would have to raise taxes or cut social services just to service its debt.

summary: Bridgewater Associates founder, Ray Dalio, has warned of the potential for a debt crisis in the US, warning that the country is headed for a crisis. The US debt has roughly tripled over the past 20 years to around $37 trillion, and annual interest payments now exceed $1 trillion. Dalio has been warning about the dangers of debt since 2018, when he published "Principles for Navigating Big Debt Crises" in his book "How Countries Go Broke," which argues that large amounts of borrowing inflating a bubble, followed by a contraction once debts become unpayable. He also warned that the US debt is close to triggering a death spiral in which the government needs to borrow more to cover its debt, and interest rates rise as holding US dollars and Treasurys becomes riskier.
shortSummary: Ray Dalio repeatedly warns about the dangers of rising US debt, citing economic dangers and political gridlock, as the country faces a potential debt crisis and economic collapse.
argos_summary: Ray Dalio warns that the U.S. is heading towards a debt crisis, with national debt tripling to around $37 trillion over the past two decades and annual interest payments reaching $1 trillion. He likens the situation to being on a boat headed for rocks, criticizing politicians for their inaction due to fear of voter backlash. Dalio has consistently highlighted the dangers of excessive borrowing, suggesting it leads to economic contractions and could trigger a 'death spiral' where the government must borrow more to cover interest payments.
